events.name: Friday Hacks #121: JS Promises and GraphQL
events.description:
This week have Chuk from from NUS ISS and Yos from Paypal talking about JavaScript Promises, and GraphQL respectively. See you there!

Date/Time: Friday, October 14 at 6:30pm 
Venue: The Hangar by NUS Enterprise 
Free pizza is served before the talks. 

Talk 1: JS Promises

Talk Description:

The promise is an important programming concept and pattern in JavaScript environment. In this session we will talk about the following:

The what and the whys of promise

Common uses of promises with examples from jQuery, Angular and Node; sequencing, coordinating parallel tasks

Monads - a general pattern

Speaker Profile

Chuk is a lecturer at NUS ISS.

Talk 2: GraphQL in an Age of REST

Talk Description:

GraphQL is an application layer query language from Facebook. With GraphQL, you can define your backend as a well-defined graph-based schema. Then client applications can query your dataset as they are needed. GraphQL’s power comes from a simple idea — instead of defining the structure of responses on the server, the flexibility is given to the client. In this talk, discover a new approach to build and expose Web APIs. Will GraphQL do to REST what REST did to SOAP?

Speaker Profile

Yos is a recent Computer Science graduate from NUS SoC, currently working as a software engineer at PayPal. In his spare time, Yos moonlights as an API fanatic and enjoys learning new things.

Our Sponsors

Friday Hacks is sponsored by NUS Enterprise.
events.location: The Hangar by NUS Enterprise, , Singapore

events.name: TGIFHacks #55 - Free Blogging w/ GitHub
events.description:
Dear Hackers,

Hi, hope you enjoyed our events last week (Hackware meetup, $PATH to iNTUition, and iNTUition v3.0). Our TGIFhacks are coming back!

Ever wanted to build a blog in a cool and customizable way without spending any money? This week, we’ll be showing you how to utilize a static website generator, named Hugo, to build your very own blog with tons of customizability. And how to publish your blog on GitHub Pages, which is completely free!

To save everyone’s time, please have an Cloud9 account (c9.io) and GitHub account (github.com) if you want to build your own blog!
events.location: The Nest Theatre @ Innovation Centre, , Singapore 63

events.name: Makers' Meetup 2016
events.description:
In conjunction with Makers' Block and Maker Festival by The Centrepoint, Singapore Makers Association presents to you the Makers' Meetup of 2016! Unlike the previous meetups, this meetup features makers' personal stories. Some make with enormous passion, while some set out to becoming an inspire entrepreneur.

We will be meeting at the Atrium, The Centrepoint, Orchard.
7pm, 14 October 2016

Highlights:- 
1) Mark Palejaro and his team will be sharing their journey as from maker to market, featuring their latest project, the "Pocket Hologram"
2) Evangeline Neo from Evacomics will be sharing her experience in creating her second book. We will have book launch and demo sessions with her.
3) Stay tuned...

Click "Going" if you're joining us. See you!

events.name: Future Fridays: Who are the Volunteers of the Future?
events.description:
What motivates people to volunteer? What can we do as fellow volunteers and as volunteer managers to engage our volunteers throughout their journey so that they (and we) remain motivated while the organisations or beneficiaries also get the help they need? Join us for this session of Future Fridays: The Future of Giving where we will use the futures wheel to explore trends that may affect volunteerism in our future. We will also use the volunteer journey map and volunteer archetypes to think about creative and sustainable ways of understanding and motivating our volunteers.

Thank you very much to Central Singapore CDC for being our venue partner! 

==

October is all about the Future of Giving! Sustainable Living Lab and (these)abilities will be examining the trends affecting what motivates volunteers, experimenting with different messages to engage them and exploring how cutting edge technologies can help create strong volunteer relationships. Whether you are a volunteer, a volunteer manager or simply curious, you can’t miss this! At the end of this series, we hope that you will understand and be inspired by the principles behind inclusive design. We also hope that whether you are a volunteer or a volunteer manager you will walk away with a toolkit that will help you to manage volunteer relationships better.

Write us at chewlin.kay@sl2square.org if you are joining us!
events.location: Central Singapore Community Development Council, HDB Hub BizThree, 490 Lorong 6 Toa Payoh, #07-11 (Lobby 2) 310490
